name: Fermat's Last Theorem
summary: Fermat's Last Theorem states that there are no positive integers \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) that can satisfy the equation \(a^{n}+b^{n}=c^{n}\) for any integer value of \(n\) greater than 2. While the equation has many integer solutions for \(n=1\) and \(n=2\) (like the Pythagorean triple \(3^{2}+4^{2}=5^{2}\)), it is impossible for any higher power. The theorem was proposed by Pierre de Fermat in 1637, but it remained unproven for over 350 years until Andrew Wiles provided a complete proof in 1994, which was published in 1995.Â
head: for all integers \(n\), if \(n\) is greater than 2
tail: then it is not true that there exist positive integers \(a,b,c\) such that \(a^{n}+b^{n}=c^{n}\).
